declarations.comments: The Web API's [MIDIAccess](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/MIDIAccess).
declarations.title: MIDIAccess

declarations.comments: Represents a single MIDI event.
declarations.title: MIDIEvent

declarations.comments: Represents a MIDI event with a timestamp.
declarations.title: MIDIEventInTime

declarations.comments: After having acquired the [MIDIAccess](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/MIDIAccess) from the browser, use it to create a streamed event of type `Event MIDIEventInTime`.
declarations.title: midi

declarations.comments: Get the [MIDIAccess](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/MIDIAccess) from the browser.
declarations.title: midiAccess

declarations.comments: Change an audio unit `node` in `igraph` with index `ptr`, outputting the changed node.
declarations.title: Change'

declarations.comments: A term that can be coerced to an setter for a control-rate audio parameter.
declarations.title: SetterVal

declarations.comments: Similar to `change'`, but accepts a record with multiple units to change.
declarations.title: change

declarations.comments: Connect node `source` from node `dest` in graph `i`, resulting in output graph `o`.
declarations.title: Connect

declarations.comments:
The initial `Frame` that is needed to begin any `Scene`.

```purescript
piece :: Scene (SceneI Unit Unit) FFIAudio (Effect Unit) Frame0
piece =
  WAGS.do
    start -- initial frame
    { time } <- env
    create (scene time) $> Right unit
    @> loop
        ( const
            $ WAGS.do
                { time } <- env
                ivoid $ change (scene time)
        )
```
declarations.title: start

declarations.comments:
Modifies the residual for a frame and returns the result.
If a frame never modifies its residual, the value of `mempty`
for `res` is returned to the scene.
declarations.title: modifyRes

declarations.comments:
Make a scene. The infix operator for this operation is `@>`.

It accepts as arguments:
- a frame to render
- a function that accepts a frame from the next moment in time (`proofB`) and returns a scene.

From these arguments, it produces a `SceneT`.

```purescript
piece :: Scene (SceneI Unit Unit) FFIAudio (Effect Unit) Frame0
piece =
  WAGS.do
    start
    { time } <- env
    create (scene time) $> Right unit
    @> loop -- here, @> is the infix version of `makeScene`
        ( const
            $ WAGS.do
                { time } <- env
                ivoid $ change (scene time)
        )
```
declarations.title: makeScene

declarations.comments: Similar to `makeScene'`, but without the possibility to branch to a new scene. Aliased as `@|>`.
declarations.title: makeScene'

declarations.comments:
Loops audio.

In WAGS, a "loop" is a universe whose `changeBit` increments by 1. That means that the structure of the graph is similar (no units added, none taken away) while some or none of its internal content (ie frequencies, gains, etc) has changed. This is accomplished using the `change` family of functions in `WAGS.Change`.

```purescript
piece :: Scene (SceneI Unit Unit) FFIAudio (Effect Unit) Frame0
piece =
  WAGS.do
    start -- initial frame
    { time } <- env
    create (scene time) $> Right unit
    @> loop -- we loop by changing the scene based on `time` in the `env`
        ( const
            $ WAGS.do
                { time } <- env
                ivoid $ change (scene time)
        )
```
declarations.title: loop

declarations.comments:
Accepts a "branch" frame for making a scene, where `Left` is a new scene and `Right` is the incoming scene with the change bit incremented by 1. Useful for the common pattern where we loop an audio graph until something in the environment changes, at which point we move on to a new graph.

```purescript
simpleScene =
  ( WAGS.do
      start
      e <- env
      create (scene0 e) $> Right unit
  )
    @> ( branch \_ -> WAGS.do
          { time } <- env
          pr <- proof
          withProof pr
            $ if time < 0.3 then
                Right
                  (
                      WAGS.do
                        e <- env
                        ivoid $ change (scene0 e)
                  )
              else
                Left
                  ( loop
                      ( const
                          $ WAGS.do
                              e <- env
                              ivoid $ change (scene1 e)
                      )
                  )
      )
```
declarations.title: branch

declarations.comments:
Often times, the computation in a frame will need to start from
universe `x` and proceed to universe `z` before continuing to
produce a scene. `inSitu` "thunks" the computation at `x`.
declarations.title: inSitu

declarations.comments: Get the current universe as a proxy.
declarations.title: universe

declarations.comments:
Get the environment from a frame.

```purescript
piece :: Scene (SceneI Unit Unit) FFIAudio (Effect Unit) Frame0
piece =
  WAGS.do
    start
    { time } <- env -- get the environment
    create (scene time) $> Right unit
    @> loop
        ( const
            $ WAGS.do
                { time } <- env
                ivoid $ change (scene time)
        )
```
declarations.title: env

declarations.comments:
Freezes the current audio frame.

```purescript
scene = (start :*> create (speaker (sinOsc 440.0))) @|> freeze
```
declarations.title: freeze

declarations.comments: Get the current graph as a proxy.
declarations.title: graph

declarations.comments: Lift a computation from the underlying monad `m` into `FrameT`.
declarations.title: lift

declarations.comments:
Get the proof term from a frame. Useful to construct a new frame using `withProof`.
The following snippet is taken from the WTK example where `proof` is used to generate a proof term that is then consumed by `withProof` in order to make the final `Frame`.

```purescript
piece :: { makeRenderingEnv :: MakeRenderingEnv } -> Scene (SceneI Trigger Unit) FFIAudio (Effect Unit) Frame0
piece { makeRenderingEnv } =
  ( WAGS.do
      start
      ivoid $ create $ fullKeyboard klavierIdentity
      k0 <- cursor $ cursors.k0
      k1 <- cursor $ cursors.k1
      k2 <- cursor $ cursors.k2
      k3 <- cursor $ cursors.k3
      k4 <- cursor $ cursors.k4
      k5 <- cursor $ cursors.k5
      k6 <- cursor $ cursors.k6
      k7 <- cursor $ cursors.k7
      k8 <- cursor $ cursors.k8
      k9 <- cursor $ cursors.k9
      myProof <- proof
      withProof myProof
        $ Right
            { audioRefs: k0 /\ k1 /\ k2 /\ k3 /\ k4 /\ k5 /\ k6 /\ k7 /\ k8 /\ k9
            , currentKeys: (Nil :: (List KeyInfo))
            , availableKeys: K0 : K1 : K2 : K3 : K4 : K5 : K6 : K7 : K8 : K9 : Nil
            }
  )
    @> loop
        ( \{ audioRefs, currentKeys, availableKeys } -> WAGS.do
            { time, trigger, active } <- env
            graphProxy <- graph
            let
              { notesOff
              , onsets
              , newCurrentKeys
              , newAvailableKeys
              , futureCurrentKeys
              , futureAvailableKeys
              } = makeRenderingEnv active trigger time availableKeys currentKeys
            ( playKeys
                { graphProxy
                , audioRefs
                , currentTime: time
                , notesOff
                }
                unit
                onsets
                newCurrentKeys
            )
              $> { audioRefs
                , currentKeys: futureCurrentKeys
                , availableKeys: futureAvailableKeys
                }
        )
```
declarations.title: proof

declarations.comments:
Consumes a `proof` term to construct a `FrameT`.
This pattern is used because `FrameT` does not implement `IxApplicative`. Instead, in order to construct a frame, one needs to provide `proof` that one is at the current moment in time. This is to prevent frames from different timestamps from mixing.
declarations.title: withProof

modules.name: WAGS.Control.Functions.Validated
modules.comments: These functions uses the `GraphIsRenderable` typeclass to assert that an audio graph is renderable by the web audio engine. This means, amongst other things, that it has a unique output device (ie speaker), that it does not have any dangling units not connected to a loudspeaker, etc.

declarations.comments:
Loops audio.

In WAGS, a "loop" is a universe whose `changeBit` increments by 1. That means that the structure of the graph is similar (no units added, none taken away) while some or none of its internal content (ie frequencies, gains, etc) has changed. This is accomplished using the `change` family of functions in `WAGS.Change`.

```purescript
piece :: Scene (SceneI Unit Unit) FFIAudio (Effect Unit) Frame0
piece =
  WAGS.do
    start -- initial frame
    { time } <- env
    create (scene time) $> Right unit
    @> loop -- we loop by changing the scene based on `time` in the `env`
        ( const
            $ WAGS.do
                { time } <- env
                ivoid $ change (scene time)
        )
```
declarations.title: loop

declarations.comments: MemoizedStateT combines the `StateT` monad and the `Env` comonad. It is similar to `StateT s (m (Env a))`. It is useful when a state combines elements that are known and unknown. The `proof` term allows producers to lock an initial state in place.
declarations.title: MemoizedStateT

declarations.comments: Run a MemoizedStateT'. The `proof` term should be the same one used to create the initial `MemoizedStateT`. `s -> s` is a transformer of the initial state provided when `makeMemoizedStateT` was called. The `s` value is discarded _unless_ no initial state was provided via a `proof` term.
declarations.title: runMemoizedStateT'

declarations.comments: `runMemoizedStateT'` for the `Identity` monad.
declarations.title: runMemoizedState'

declarations.comments: `runMemoizedStateT'` without a transformer for the initial state.
declarations.title: runMemoizedStateT

declarations.comments: `runMemoizedStateT'` without a transformer for the initial state & for the `Identity` monad.
declarations.title: runMemoizedState

declarations.comments: Given `proof`, create a `MemoizedStateT` with an initial state.
declarations.title: makeMemoizedStateT

declarations.comments: Given `proof`, create a `MemoizedState` with an initial state.
declarations.title: makeMemoizedState

modules.name: WAGS.Control.Qualified
modules.comments:
Import this module to use `do` notation with `FrameT`.
This qualified file is needed because `FrameT` does not implement `IxMonad`.

declarations.comments: Thunkable is the [`Trampoline`](https://pursuit.purescript.org/packages/purescript-free/6.0.0/docs/Control.Monad.Trampoline#t:Trampoline) moand with some extra typeclasses like `Alt` and `Plus` and some extra utility methods for thunking.
declarations.title: Thunkable

declarations.comments: Returns `true` if the `Thunkable` is a `Wait`, else `false`.
declarations.title: isWait

declarations.comments: Returns `true` if the `Thunkable` is a `Here`, else `false`.
declarations.title: isHere

declarations.comments: Runs a thunkable to produce an `a`. Same as [`runTrampoline`](https://pursuit.purescript.org/packages/purescript-free/6.0.0/docs/Control.Monad.Trampoline#v:runTrampoline).
declarations.title: runThunkable

declarations.comments: Runs a thunkable to produce an `a`, counting how many "thunks" were needed.
declarations.title: runThunkableWithCount

declarations.comments: Thunks a thunkable once, producing a new thunkable. Same as [`runFree`](https://pursuit.purescript.org/packages/purescript-free/6.0.0/docs/Control.Monad.Free#v:runFree).
declarations.title: thunkThunkable

declarations.comments: A natural transformation from `Thunkable` to any monad `m`. Same as [`foldFree`](https://pursuit.purescript.org/packages/purescript-free/6.0.0/docs/Control.Monad.Free#v:foldFree).
declarations.title: monadifyThunkable

declarations.comments: A natural transformation from `Thunkable` to any monad `m` that inserts `m Unit` in between thunks.
declarations.title: intercalateThunkable

declarations.comments: A natural transformation from `Thunkable` to `Aff` that guarantees the `Wait` operation will resume on the next tick of a browser or node event loop.
declarations.title: affifyThunkable

declarations.comments: Waitable is a something that can be told to wait.
declarations.title: Waitable

declarations.comments:
Represents a single frame of an audio scene. Conceptually, this is a snapshot in time of audio.

- `env`: The outside environment influencing audio. Contains things like mouse clicks, the current time, and MIDI events.
- `audio`: The audio context. This is `Unit` when testing and `FFIAudio` when rendering actual audio.
- `engine`: The type output by the audio rendering engine. This is `Instruction` when testing and `Effect Unit` when rendering actual audio.
- `proof`: A proof term representing the current moment in time. `proof` is a type-safe way to make sure that a frame at time `n` is not composed (ie via bind) with a frame at time `n + 1`.
- `m`: The underlying monad in which the information of the frame lies. Usually this is `Thunkable` but can also be `Identity` or `Aff` depending on your use case.
- `res`: A monoid containing a residual from the audio computation. Use this if you need to pass computations from an audio graph to downstream consumers. In general, it is best if computations happen before audio graph rendering, so it's best to use `res` only in cases where a computation is dependent on values that can only be calculated in the audio-graph, ie scheduling based on the audio clock.
- `iu`: The input `Graph`, meaning the state of the frame before a computation.
- `ou`: The output `Graph`, meaning the state of the frame after a computation.
- `a`: The term within the frame. This is often some form of accumulator that represents an evolving state over time.

> NB: `FrameT` does not implement `IxApplicative` because we never want to be able to pull a `proof` term out of thin air. It does, however, have a `bind` operation in `WAGS.Control.Qualified` that can is used for rebindable `do` notation in all of the tests and examples.
declarations.title: FrameT

declarations.comments: A `FrameT` specialized to the `Thunkable` monad.
declarations.title: Frame

declarations.comments: Type used for the internal representation of the current audio state.
declarations.title: AudioState

declarations.comments: Type used for the internal representation of the current audio state.
declarations.title: AudioState'

declarations.comments: The `Graph` at which any scene starts.
declarations.title: InitialGraph

declarations.comments: The `FrameT` at which any scene starts.
declarations.title: InitialFrameT

declarations.comments: The `Frame` at which any scene starts.
declarations.title: InitialFrame

declarations.comments: A `proof` term for the initial frame.
declarations.title: Frame0

declarations.comments: `oneFrame` is `oneFrameT` specialized for the `Thunkable` monad.
declarations.title: oneFrame

declarations.comments: This represents the output of `oneFrame` as a tuple instead of a record.
declarations.title: oneFrame'

declarations.comments: Given an `env`, gets the next `SceneT'` from a `SceneT`.
declarations.title: oneFrameT

declarations.comments: This represents the output of `oneFrameT` as a tuple instead of a record.
declarations.title: oneFrameT'

declarations.comments: "For office use only" way to access the innards of a frame. Obliterates type safety. Use at your own risk.
declarations.title: unsafeUnframe

declarations.comments: "For office use only" way to construct a frame. Obliterates type safety. Use at your own risk.
declarations.title: unsafeFrame

declarations.comments: Similar to `create`, but accepts a record with multiple units to create _and_ connect.
declarations.title: create

declarations.comments: Create an audio unit `node` in `igraph` with index `ptr`, resulting in `ograph`.
declarations.title: Create'

declarations.comments: A value that can be coerced to an initial control-rate audio parameter.
declarations.title: InitialVal

declarations.comments: Destroy node `ptr` in graph `i`, resulting in graph `o`. Note that, to destroy a node, it must have no outgoing or incoming edges. This is achieved via use of `disconnect`. Failure to disconnect nodes before destroying will result in a compile-time error during graph validation.
declarations.title: Destroy

declarations.comments: Internal helper class used for destroing audio nodes.
declarations.title: PointerNotPresentInAnyEdgeList

declarations.comments: Disconnect node `source` from node `dest` in graph `i`, resulting in output graph `o`.
declarations.title: Disconnect

declarations.comments: Get an audio unit `node` in `igraph` with index `ptr`.
declarations.title: Get'

declarations.comments: Similar to `get'`, but accepts a record with multiple units to get.
declarations.title: get

declarations.comments:
Term-level constructor for an allpass filter.
- `frequency` - the frequency where the phase transition occurs.
- `q` - the width of the filter.
declarations.title: Allpass

declarations.comments:
Term-level constructor for a bandpass filter.
- `frequency` - the frequency of the isolated band.
- `q` - the width of the filter.
declarations.title: Bandpass

declarations.comments:
Term-level constructor for a constant value, aka DC offset.
- `OnOff` - whether the generator is on or off.
- `offset` - the amount of DC offset.
declarations.title: Constant

declarations.comments:
Term-level constructor for a convolver, aka reverb.
- `buffer` - the buffer of the impulse response of the space.
declarations.title: Convolver

declarations.comments:
Term-level constructor for a delay unit.
- `delay` - the delay to apply.
declarations.title: Delay

declarations.comments:
Term-level constructor for a compressor.
- `threshold` - The threshold under which compression kicks in.
- `knee` - The kink of the compression.
- `ratio` - The amount of compression to apply.
- `attack` - How far we look ahead. Longer attacks will lead to more crisp compression at the expense of an audible delay.
- `release` - How long the release time of compression should be.
declarations.title: DynamicsCompressor

declarations.comments:
Term-level constructor for a gain unit.
- `volume` - the volume of the gain from 0 to 1.
declarations.title: Gain

declarations.comments:
Term-level constructor for a highpass filter.
- `frequency` - the frequency below which we start to filter.
- `q` - the width of the filter.
declarations.title: Highpass

declarations.comments:
Term-level constructor for a highshelf filter.
- `frequency` - the frequency above which we start to filter.
- `gain` - the boost or the amount of attenuation to apply.
declarations.title: Highshelf

declarations.comments:
Term-level constructor for a looping buffer.
- `buffer` - a string representing the buffer to use. Note that this string, when reset, will only reset the buffer when it is stopped.
- `OnOff` - whether or not the generator is on or off.
- `playbackRate` - the playback rate.
- `Number` - where in the file the loop should start.
- `Number` - where in the file the loop should end. A value of 0.0 or less means play to the end of the buffer.
declarations.title: LoopBuf

declarations.comments:
Term-level constructor for a lowpass filter.
- `frequency` - the frequency above which we start to filter.
- `q` - the width of the filter.
declarations.title: Lowpass

declarations.comments:
Term-level constructor for a lowshelf filter.
- `frequency` - the frequency below which we start to filter.
- `q` - the width of the filter.
declarations.title: Lowshelf

declarations.comments: Term-level constructor for a microphone
declarations.title: Microphone

declarations.comments:
Term-level constructor for a notch (aka band-reject) filter.
- `frequency` - the frequency we are rejecting.
- `q` - the width of the filter.
declarations.title: Notch

declarations.comments:
Term-level constructor for a peaking filter. A peaking filter is a combination of bandpass and notch where the gain parameter modulates whether we are reinforcing or attenuating a frequency.
- `frequency` - the frequency we are emphasizing _or_ rejecting.
- `q` - the width of the filter.
- `gain` - if positive, we are emphasizing the frequency. If negative, we are rejecting it.
declarations.title: Peaking

declarations.comments:
Term-level constructor for a periodic oscillator.
- `periodicOsc` - the name of the wave table we'll be using. Note that, for a chance to take effect, the periodic oscillator must be stopped.
- `OnOff` - whether the generator is on or off.
- `frequency` - the frequency of the oscillator.
declarations.title: PeriodicOsc

declarations.comments:
Term-level constructor for a playback buffer.
- `buffer` - a string representing the buffer to use. Note that this string, when reset, will only reset the buffer when it is stopped.
- `Number` - where in the file the playback should start.
- `OnOff` - whether or not the generator is on or off.
- `playbackRate` - the playback rate.
declarations.title: PlayBuf

declarations.comments:
Term-level constructor for a recorder.
- `recorder` - the recorder to which we write data.
declarations.title: Recorder

declarations.comments:
Term-level constructor for a sawtooth oscillator.
- `OnOff` - whether the generator is on or off.
- `frequency` - the frequency of the oscillator.
declarations.title: SawtoothOsc

declarations.comments:
Term-level constructor for a sine-wave oscillator.
- `OnOff` - whether the generator is on or off.
- `frequency` - the frequency of the oscillator.
declarations.title: SinOsc

declarations.comments: Term-level constructor for a loudspeaker.
declarations.title: Speaker

declarations.comments:
Term-level constructor for a square-wave oscillator.
- `OnOff` - whether the generator is on or off.
- `frequency` - the frequency of the oscillator.
declarations.title: SquareOsc

declarations.comments:
Term-level constructor for a stereo panner.
- `pan` - the amount of pan to apply, where -1.0 is fully to the left and 1.0 is fully to the right.
declarations.title: StereoPanner

declarations.comments:
Term-level constructor for a triangle oscillator.
- `OnOff` - whether the generator is on or off.
- `frequency` - the frequency of the oscillator.
declarations.title: TriangleOsc

declarations.comments:
Term-level constructor for a WaveShaper, aka distortion.
- `floatArray` - the shape of the distortion.
- `oversample` - how much to oversample - none, 2x or 4x. Once set, this cannot change without destroying and remaking the audio unit.
declarations.title: WaveShaper

declarations.comments: Term-level constructor for a generator being on or off
declarations.title: OnOff

declarations.comments: Type-level oversample none for a wave shaper. This is at the type-level and not the term-level via an ADT because we need make sure to construct an entirely new wave shaper if the value changes.
declarations.title: OversampleNone

declarations.comments: Type-level oversample 2x for a wave shaper. This is at the type-level and not the term-level via an ADT because we need make sure to construct an entirely new wave shaper if the value changes.
declarations.title: OversampleTwoX

declarations.comments: Type-level oversample 4x for a wave shaper. This is at the type-level and not the term-level via an ADT because we need make sure to construct an entirely new wave shaper if the value changes.
declarations.title: OversampleFourX

declarations.comments: Type-level constructor for an allpass filter.
declarations.title: TAllpass

declarations.comments: Type-level constructor for a bandpass filter.
declarations.title: TBandpass

declarations.comments: Type-level constructor for a constant value.
declarations.title: TConstant

declarations.comments: Type-level constructor for a convolver, aka reverb.
declarations.title: TConvolver

declarations.comments: Type-level constructor for a delay unit.
declarations.title: TDelay

declarations.comments: Type-level constructor for a compressor.
declarations.title: TDynamicsCompressor

declarations.comments: Type-level constructor for a gain unit.
declarations.title: TGain

declarations.comments: Type-level constructor for a highpass filter.
declarations.title: THighpass

declarations.comments: Type-level constructor for a highshelf filter.
declarations.title: THighshelf

declarations.comments: Type-level constructor for a looping buffer.
declarations.title: TLoopBuf

declarations.comments: Type-level constructor for a lowpass filter.
declarations.title: TLowpass

declarations.comments: Type-level constructor for a lowshelf filter.
declarations.title: TLowshelf

declarations.comments: Type-level constructor for a microphone.
declarations.title: TMicrophone

declarations.comments: Type-level constructor for a notch filter.
declarations.title: TNotch

declarations.comments: Type-level constructor for a peaking filter.
declarations.title: TPeaking

declarations.comments: Type-level constructor for a periodic oscillator.
declarations.title: TPeriodicOsc

declarations.comments: Type-level constructor for playback from a buffer.
declarations.title: TPlayBuf

declarations.comments: Type-level constructor for a recorder.
declarations.title: TRecorder

declarations.comments: Type-level constructor for a sawtooth oscillator.
declarations.title: TSawtoothOsc

declarations.comments: Type-level constructor for a sine-wave oscillator.
declarations.title: TSinOsc

declarations.comments: Type-level constructor for a loudspeaker.
declarations.title: TSpeaker

declarations.comments: Type-level constructor for a square-wave oscillator.
declarations.title: TSquareOsc

declarations.comments: Type-level constructor for a stereo panner.
declarations.title: TStereoPanner

declarations.comments: Type-level constructor for a triangle oscillator.
declarations.title: TTriangleOsc

declarations.comments: Type-level constructor for a wave shaper.
declarations.title: TWaveShaper

declarations.comments: Reify many audio units.
declarations.title: reifyAUs

declarations.comments: A row of edges going into a node.
declarations.title: Edges

declarations.comments: A list of edges going into a node.
declarations.title: EdgeList

declarations.comments: A graph of audio nodes.

modules.name: WAGS.Graph.Optionals
modules.comments: This module provides functions for the construction of audio units that more closely resemble the overloaded constructors of the Web Audio API.

children.title: allpass
allpass_

declarations.comments: The type of a created allpass filter
declarations.title: CAllpass

declarations.comments: The type of a changing allpass filter

children.title: bandpass
bandpass_

children.comments:
Change a constant value

```purescript
constant_ 0.5
constant_ On 0.5
```

Make a constant value

```purescript
constant 0.5
constant On 0.5
```

declarations.comments:
Make a convolver, aka reverb.

```purescript
convolver (Proxy :: _ "room") (playBuf "track")
```

Make a delay unit.

```purescript
delay 0.5 (playBuf "track")
```

children.title: compressor_
compressor

declarations.comments:
Mix together several audio units

```purescript
mix (playBuf (Proxy :: _ "hello") /\ playBuf (Proxy :: _ "world") /\ unit)
```

declarations.comments: A reference to a node in a graph.
declarations.title: Ref

declarations.comments: A reference to a node in a graph.
declarations.title: ref

declarations.comments: Class to determine if a type is an oversample directive.
declarations.title: IsOversample

declarations.comments: A control-rate audio parameter as a newtype.
declarations.title: AudioParameter_

declarations.comments:
A control-rate audio parameter.

`param`: The parameter as a floating-point value _or_ an instruction to cancel all future parameters.
`timeOffset`: How far ahead of the current playhead to set the parameter. This can be used in conjunction with the `headroom` parameter in `run` to execute precisely-timed events. For example, if the `headroom` is `20ms` and an attack should happen in `10ms`, use `timeOffset: 10.0` to make sure that the taret parameter happens exactly at the point of attack.
`transition`: Transition between two points in time.
declarations.title: AudioParameter_'

declarations.comments:
A transition between two points in time.
- `NoRamp` is a discrete step.
- `LinearRamp` is linear interpolation between two values.
- `ExponentialRamp` is exponential interpolation between two values.
- `Immediately` erases the current value and replaces it with this one. Different than `NoRamp` in that it does not take into account scheduling and executes immediately. Useful for responsive instruments.
declarations.title: AudioParameterTransition

declarations.comments: Create an audio parameter from a number using default parameters.
declarations.title: param

declarations.comments:
A default audio parameter.

defaultParam = { param: 0.0, timeOffset: 0.0, transition: LinearRamp }
declarations.title: defaultParam

modules.name: WAGS.Interpret
modules.comments:
Interpret audio in an engine using the `AudioInterpret` class.

WAGS ships with two engines - `Effect Unit` for real audio and `Instruction` for an ADT representation of audio.

children.comments: Connect pointer x to pointer y. For example, connect a sine wave oscillator to a highpass filter.
children.title: connectXToY

children.comments: Disconnect pointer x from pointer y. For example, disconnect a sine wave oscillator from a gain unit.
children.title: disconnectXFromY

children.comments: Destroy pointer x. For example, drop a sine wave oscillator from an audio graph. Note that this does not invoke garbage collection - it just removes the reference to the node, allowing it to be garbage collected.
children.title: destroyUnit

children.comments: Make an allpass filter.
children.title: makeAllpass

children.comments: Make a bandpass filter.

children.comments: Make a constant source, ie a stream of 0s.

declarations.comments:
A class with all possible instructions for interpreting audio.
The class is paramaterized by two types:
- `audio`: an audio context, which could be nothing (ie `Unit`) if there is audio or `FFIAudio` if there is audio.
- `engine`: the output of the engine. For real audio, this is `Effect Unit`, as playing something from a loudspeaker is a side effect that doesn't return anything. For testing, this is the `Instruction` type, which is an ADT representation of instructions to an audio engine.
declarations.title: AudioInterpret

declarations.comments: A multi-channel audio buffer.
declarations.title: AudioBuffer

declarations.comments: An [AudioContext](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/AudioContext)
declarations.title: AudioContext

declarations.comments: An [AudioBuffer](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/AudioBuffer).
declarations.title: BrowserAudioBuffer

declarations.comments: The [MediaStream](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/MediaStream) object for a camera.
declarations.title: BrowserCamera

declarations.comments: A [Float32Array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Float32Array)
declarations.title: BrowserFloatArray

declarations.comments: The [MediaStream](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/MediaStream) object for a microphone.
declarations.title: BrowserMicrophone

declarations.comments: A [PeriodicWave](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/PeriodicWave).
declarations.title: BrowserPeriodicWave

declarations.comments:
The audio information that goes to the ffi during rendering.

- `context` - the audio context. To create an `AudioContext`, use `context`.
- `writeHead` - the moment in time in the audio context at which we are writing. The easing algorithm provided to run makes sure that this is always slightly ahead of the actual audio context time. When starting a scene, this should be set to `0.0`.
- `units` - an object in which audio units are cached and retrieved. To create this, use `makeUnitCache`.
- `microphone` - the browser microphone or `null` if we do not have one.
- `recorders` - an object recorder rendering functions. Because media recorders do not yet exist when a scene starts, we provide rendering functions and then fill in the actual recorders once the rendering starts.
- `buffers` - an object containing named audio buffers for playback using `PlayBuf` or `LoopBuf`. See the `atari-speaks` example to see how a buffer is used.
- `floatArrays` - arrays of 32=bit floats used for wave shaping.
- `periodicWaves` - array of periodic waves used for creating oscillator nodes.
declarations.title: FFIAudio'

declarations.comments: An AudioParameter with the `transition` field stringly-typed for easier rendering in the FFI and cancelation as a boolean
declarations.title: FFIAudioParameter'

declarations.comments: A [MediaRecorder](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/MediaRecorder).
declarations.title: MediaRecorder

declarations.comments: Make a multi-channel audio buffer. Each vector into the multi-channel buffer must be the same length.
declarations.title: audioBuffer

declarations.comments: For a given audio context, add the audio worklet module at a given URI.
declarations.title: audioWorkletAddModule

declarations.comments: Close an audio context.
declarations.title: close

declarations.comments: Make a new audio context.
declarations.title: context

declarations.comments: Given an audio context and a base-64-encoded audio file, decode the content of the string to an audio buffer.
declarations.title: decodeAudioDataFromBase64EncodedString

declarations.comments: Given an audio context and a URI, decode the content of the URI to an audio buffer.
declarations.title: decodeAudioDataFromUri

declarations.comments: Gets the audio clock time from an audio context.
declarations.title: getAudioClockTime

declarations.comments: Is this MIME type supported by this browser.
declarations.title: isTypeSupported

declarations.comments: For a given audio context, use an audio buffer to create a browser audio buffer. This is useful when doing DSP in the browser.  Note that `AudioBuffer` is a purescript type whereas `BrowserAudioBuffer` is an optimized browser-based type. That means that, once you write to `BrowserAudioBuffer`, it is effectively a blob and its contents cannot be retrieved using the WAGS API.
declarations.title: makeAudioBuffer

declarations.comments: Make a float 32 array. Useful when creating a waveshaper node.
declarations.title: makeFloatArray

declarations.comments:
Make a browser periodic wave. A PureScript-ified version of the periodic wave constructor
from the [Web Audio API](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/PeriodicWave/PeriodicWave).
Given an audio context, a vector of real parts of complex numbers, and a vector of imaginary parts of complex numbers, build a periodic wave interpretable by the Web Audio API.
declarations.title: makePeriodicWave

declarations.comments: Create a unit cache. This returns a fresh empty object `{}` that is used to cache audio units.
declarations.title: makeUnitCache

declarations.comments:
For a given MIME type, pass the URL-ified content of a media recorder as a string to a handler.

```purescript
mediaRecorderToUrl "audio/ogg" setAudioTagUrlToThisContent recorder
```
declarations.title: mediaRecorderToUrl

declarations.comments:
Render audio from an array of audio rendering instructions. This is conceptually the same as
taking `Array Effect Unit -> Effect Unit` and doing `map fold <<< sequence`.
The reason this version is used is because it is ~2x more computationally efficient,
which is important in order to be able to hit audio deadlines.
declarations.title: renderAudio

declarations.comments: Stops a media recorder
declarations.title: stopMediaRecorder

modules.name: WAGS.Rendered
modules.comments:
Term-level representations of the typelevel graph. These are
emitted by `run` and can be used to visualize the audio graph.
These representations are also used interally to speed up graph
rendering and to validate the graph in unit tests.

declarations.comments: The amount a [WaveShaperNode](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WaveShaperNode) should oversample.
declarations.title: Oversample

declarations.comments:
A term-level representation of audio units. Used for testing as well as internally to
represent the audio graph. They are also present in the output of `run` for downstream
graph visualization.
declarations.title: AnAudioUnit

modules.name: WAGS.Run
modules.comments: Run a `Scene` to produce sound using the Web Audio API.

declarations.comments:
An algorithm that tells the engine how much lookahead the audio should have in milliseconds. The `(->) Int` is a penalty function, where a positive input is the number of milliseconds left over after rendering (meaning we gave too much headroom) and a negative input is the number of milliseconds by which we missed the deadline (meaning there was not enough headroom). This allows the algorithm to make adjustments if necessary.

As an example:

```purescript
easingAlgorithm :: EasingAlgorithm
easingAlgorithm =
  let
    fOf initialTime = mkCofree initialTime \adj -> fOf $ max 20 (initialTime - adj)
  in
    fOf 20
```

This easing algorithm always provides at least 20ms of headroom to the algorithm, but adjusts upwards in case deadlines are being missed.
declarations.title: EasingAlgorithm

declarations.comments: The information provided to `run` that tells the engine how to make certain rendering tradeoffs.
declarations.title: EngineInfo

declarations.comments:
The output of `run` to be consumed downstream (or not). It contains:
- `nodes`: the nodes in the audio graph including information about things like their frequency, Q value, on/off state etc.
- `edges`: incoming edges into nodes.
- `res`: the residual from the computation.

This information can be used for visualizing the audio graph or for other instruments outside of a browser that are using the browser as a control layer.
declarations.title: Run

declarations.comments:
The input type to a scene that is handled by `run`. Given `Event trigger` and `Behavior world`, the scene will receive:

`trigger` - the trigger.
`world` - the world.
`time` - the time of the audio context.
`sysTime` - the time provided by `new Date().getTime()`
`active` - whether this event was caused by a trigger or is a measurement of the world. This is useful to not repeat onsets from the trigger.
`headroom` - the amount of lookahead time. If you are programming a precise rhythmic event and need the onset to occur at a specific moment, you can use `headroom` to determine if the apex should happen now or later.
declarations.title: SceneI

declarations.comments:
Given a buffering window and an event, return a list of events that occur within that window.
- `timeToCollect` - the buffering window
- `incomingEvent` - the event to buffer

For example, if `event` outputs the following sequence:

- `unit` @ 0 ms
- `unit` @ 1 ms
- `unit` @ 7 ms
- `unit` @ 9 ms
- `unit` @ 15 ms

Then:

```purescript
bufferToList 4 event
```

would group together events within the same 4ms window before emitting them, resulting in

```purescript
{ time :: 0ms, value :: unit } : { time :: 1ms, value :: unit } : Nil -- emitted at 4ms
{ time :: 7ms, value :: unit } : { time :: 9ms, value :: unit } : Nil -- emitted at 11ms
{ time :: 15ms, value :: unit } : Nil -- emitted at 19ms
```
declarations.title: bufferToList

declarations.comments:
Run a scene.

- `Event trigger` is the event to which the scene reacts. `trigger` will contain things like an initial event, mouse clicks, MIDI onsets, OSC commands and any other event to which the scene should respond.  Because of this, the polymorphic type `trigger` is often defined as an ADT with different potential incoming actions, similar to how [actions are defined in Halogen](https://github.com/purescript-halogen/purescript-halogen/blob/master/docs/guide/02-Introducing-Components.md#actions). Note that no sound will be produced unless there is _at least_ one event. For this reason, there is usually some form of initial event, ie `data Trigger = InitialEvent | MouseClick | etc..`, that is sent to start audio rendering. All of the examples in this repo contain an initial event, which is often `pure unit` in the case where there in _only_ the initial event.
- `Behavior world` is the outside environment. `world` will usually contain things like the current mouse position, the ambient temperature, the axial tilt of the Earth, or other things that can be modeled as a continuous function of time. One important thing to note is that `world` _lags_ `trigger` by 0 or 1 events in the [browser event queue](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/EventLoop). For most real-world applications, this does not matter, but it does lead to subtle logic bugs if `trigger` and `world` are corrolated. For this reason, it is good to decouple `trigger` and `world`.
- `EngineInfo` is the engine information needed for rendering.
- `FFIAudio` is the audio state needed for rendering
- `Scene` is the scene to render. See `SceneI` to understand how `trigger` and `world` are blended into the inptu environment going to `Scene`.
declarations.title: run

modules.name: WAGS.Util
modules.comments: This module contains utility typeclasses for various type-level programs.

declarations.comments:
Type-equality as a true/false assertion. Like
[TypeEquals](https://pursuit.purescript.org/packages/purescript-type-equality/3.0.0/docs/Type.Equality#t:TypeEquals), but allows us to encode the failure case.
declarations.title: TypeEqualTF

declarations.comments: Assertion that `a` is less than `b`
declarations.title: LtEq

modules.name: WAGS.Validation
modules.comments:
Validation algorithms for audio graphs.

Validation includes making sure the graph is renderable by
the web audio API and retrieving information about valid graphs,
like their terminal node (ie a loudspeaker).

declarations.comments:
Asserts that an audio graph is renderable.

Every time that `makeScene` is called, we assert that the graph is
renderable. This means that it can be played by the WebAudio API
without any runtime errors. Note that this assertion is a
_compile time_ assertion and not a _runtime_ assertion. This means that,
when your program is compiled, it is guaranteed to be renderable by
the WebAudio API _assuming that_ it is within the memory constraints
of a given browser and computer. Usually, these memory limits are not
hit unless one has hundreds of active nodes.
declarations.title: GraphIsRenderable

declarations.comments:
Retrieves the terminal node from an audio grpah. This is
almost always a speaker or recording, but if the graph is
at an intermediary stage of construction, this could be another
top-level node, ie a gain node.
declarations.title: TerminalNodeC

declarations.comments: Assert that all edges are present as nodes in a graph
declarations.title: AllEdgesInGraph'

declarations.comments: Assert that all edges are present as nodes in a graph
declarations.title: AllEdgesInGraph

declarations.comments: Assertion that all edges in the graph point to a node in the graph.
declarations.title: AllEdgesPointToNodes

declarations.comments: Assertion that `nodeList` contains no parallel edges. Parallel edges are two or more edges from `node1` to `node2` in a list of nodes.
declarations.title: NoParallelEdgesNL

declarations.comments: Assertion that `graph` contains no parallel edges. Parallel edges are two or more edges from `node1` to `node2` in a list of nodes.
declarations.title: NoParallelEdges

declarations.comments:
Tail-recursive lookup of all nodes in a graph without incoming edges.
- `nodeList` is the list of nodes that will be searched over.
- `output` contains all nodes without incoming edges.
declarations.title: SourceNodes

declarations.comments: Assertion that a graph has source nodes. Source nodes are nodes without incoming edges.
declarations.title: HasSourceNodes

declarations.comments: The algorithm that finds the terminal nodes of a graph.
declarations.title: GetTerminii

declarations.comments:
Assertion that `graph` has the unique terminus `node`. Note that,
due to the fundep, the assertion also _finds_ the unique terminus
if it exists.
declarations.title: UniqueTerminus

declarations.comments: Assertion that `graph` has a unique terminus.
declarations.title: HasUniqueTerminus

declarations.comments:
Asserts that all nodes in `graph` are saturated.
"Saturation" for audio nodes is similar to the concept of saturation
in types, namely that they have all the information necessary to
render. In doing so, it also fails the assertion on degenerate nodes,
ie sine-wave oscillators with input (which wouldn't make sense).
declarations.title: AllNodesAreSaturatedNL

declarations.comments:
Asserts that all nodes in `graph` are saturated. This is
the same as the node-list algorithm, but for a graph.
declarations.title: AllNodesAreSaturated

declarations.comments:
Asserts the node is an output device. Currently, in the web-audio API,
this is a loudspeaker or recorder.
declarations.title: NodeIsOutputDevice
